It is highly significant to develop effective catalysts made from non-precious metals for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process of eugenol to propylcyclohexane. A triazine polymer (PAF-53) was employed as a template to synthesize a highly potential Co/NC-T (nitrogen-doped carbon modified by template) catalyst through one-pot pyrolysis method, aiming to facilitate the HDO reaction of eugenol. The results of the characterization indicated that Co nanoparticles (NPs) were incorporated within the structure of nitrogen-doped carbon. Adding the suitable quantity of PAF-53 could improve the distribution of Co NPs, increase the specific area and average pore diameter, and facilitate the generation of numerous carbon nanotubes that are sparse and porous. Furthermore, the incorporation of PAF-53 improved the interaction between Co and nitrogen-doped carbon, and endowed Co/NC-T with high mobile electrons. As revealed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the adsorption of eugenol molecules was obviously enhanced, and the parallel adsorption configuration was remarkably favorable. The conversion of eugenol over Co/NC-T-1:4 reached 100% and the selectivity of propylcyclohexane reached 98.4%, at 300 °C, 3 MPa H2 and a liquid hourly space velocity of 12 h−1. Moreover, the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst exhibited remarkable durability and scalability during the HDO process of eugenol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cobalt Carbon nanotubes Propylcyclohexane Hydrodeoxygenation Eugenol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The use of biomass as an alternative energy source has garnered significant interest [1,2]. Pyrolysis of biomass is a common method for producing bio-oil [3]. Nevertheless, the unrefined bio-oil possesses certain unfavorable qualities such as poor instability, low calorific value, and low value of pH, thereby restricting its viable use as a substitute fuel for transportation [4]. Therefore, further upgrading of the crude bio-oil is essential. The removal of oxygen by hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) from crude bio-oil is the focus of the upgrading process. The oxygenated compounds in bio-oil primarily consist of phenols, aldehydes, ketones, esters, alcohols, acids, and ethers [5,6]. Eugenol, guaiacol, phenol, and vanillin are the representative phenols found in bio-oils. Due to the attachment of phenolic hydroxyl groups to the benzene ring, the process of removing oxygen directly by HDO from phenolic compounds poses a challenge in the upgrading of bio-oil [7–9]. The molecular structure of eugenol consists of three different functional groups (Scheme 1 ): methoxy, hydroxyl, and alkenyl groups. Additionally, it possesses three distinct types of CO bonds: Calkyl-O (with a BDE of 200 kJ/mol), Caryl–OCH3 (with a BDE of 386.5 kJ/mol), and Caryl-OH (with a BDE of 452 kJ/mol) [10]. Multiple products including aromatic and cycloalkane compounds may be generated in the hydrogenation process of eugenol (Scheme 1). Various catalyst active components, including precious metals like Pd [11], Ru [12,13], and RuRe [14], as well as non-precious metal components like NiP [15], Ni [16–18], NiFe [19], and NiCo [20,21], have been studied for the HDO of eugenol in recent years (Table S1). Furthermore, the role of various support materials in enhancing the catalytic efficiency of HDO has been examined. These support materials encompass carbon materials [14,19], HZSM-5 [15], Al-SBA-15 [17], SiO2 [16], and NbOx [21]. In recent times, there has been growing interest in carbon materials [22,23], particularly nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) materials [24,25]. The introduction of nitrogen into carbon structures can bring about significant alterations in the physical and chemical characteristics of carbon materials, including changes in basicity [26] and catalytic activity [27–29]. Hence, carbon materials doped with nitrogen exhibit excellent performance in diverse applications, including supercapacitors [30], oxidation–reduction reaction catalysts [31], and catalyst supports [32–33]. For example, NC materials exhibited outstanding effectiveness in stabilizing Pd nanoparticles (NPs), resulting in Pd@NC catalysts that demonstrated remarkable catalytic activity in the HDO of vanillin [34]. The metal catalysts loaded with NC can be prepared using a single-step pyrolysis technique [35–37]. Precursors such as metal complexes [38,39] and metal-organic-frameworks [40] have been used to prepare metal/NC materials. However, the properties of NC materials are variable, and it is still challenging to regulate the interaction between NC materials and metals in a targeted way and to prepare metal catalysts with specific functions. Herein, a unique template triazine polymer known as a porous aromatic framework (PAF-53) was utilized to fabricate Co/nitrogen-doped carbon materials through a one-step pyrolysis method. The dicyandiamide was introduced as an additional carbon-nitrogen source. Consequently, nitrogen-doped carbon modified by template (NC-T) which contained a large number of carbon nanotubes was formed, effectively immobilizing Co NPs. The Co/NC-T catalysts showed outstanding performance in the HDO process of eugenol to propylcyclohexane, surpassing the performance of the multiple catalysts (Table S1). 2 Experimental and theoretical calculations 2.1 Materials Shanghai Maclean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. provided cobalt nitrate [Co(NO3)2·6H2O], dicyandiamide (AR, 99%) and eugenol (AR, 99%). Shanghai Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. supplied melamine (AR, 99%) and p-phenylenediamine (AR, 99%). Methanol was acquired from Chengdu Chron Chemical Co., Ltd. No further purification was performed on any of the reagents. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of PAF-53 Melamine (1.84 g) was dissolved in 50 mL of methanol, resulting in solution A, while p-phenylenediamine (1.62 g) was dissolved in 30 mL of methanol, resulting in solution B. Afterwards, solution B was introduced into solution A while stirring, resulting in the formation of a homogeneous white flocculent precipitate. The resulting mixture was continuously stirred for 6 h, followed by filtration and vacuum drying at 40 °C for 12 h to yield PAF-53. 2.2.2 Preparation of Co/NC catalysts In 60 mL of deionized water, 4.37 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 15.0 g of dicyandiamide were completely dissolved. The solution obtained was mixed using magnetic stirring for 30 min, and then subjected to sonication for 2 h. Afterward, the solution was allowed to stand for 4 h and subsequently dried overnight at 80 °C under vacuum. The resulting precursor (denoted as Co/NC precursor) was slowly heated to 600 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min in an atmosphere of N2. The mixture was kept at this temperature for 2 h. Subsequently, it was heated to 900 °C at a rate of 3 °C/ min and maintained for another 2 h. After natural cooling, the resultant catalyst, referred to as Co/NC, was acquired. The yield of Co/NC calculated based on mass sum of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and dicyandiamide was approximately 7.4%. The Co/NC catalysts that were prepared were also named Co/NC-650, Co/NC-700, Co/NC-800, Co/NC-900, and Co/NC-1000, which corresponded to pyrolysis temperatures of 650 °C, 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C, and 1000 °C, respectively. 2.2.3 Preparation of the Co/CN2N and Co/NC-T catalysts Using 4.37 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 15.0 g of PAF-53 as starting materials, Co/CN2N catalyst was synthesized following a procedure similar to that used for the Co/NC catalysts. The yield of Co/CN2N calculated based on mass of starting materials was approximately 25.3%. Moreover, Co/NC-T catalysts modified by template were synthesized using a comparable method, albeit with the replacement of dicyandiamide by different weight proportions of PAF-53 and dicyandiamide. The Co/NC-T catalysts, denoted as Co/NC-T-1:9, Co/NC-T-1:4, Co/NC-T-3:2, and Co/NC-T-4:1, were prepared using mass ratios of PAF-53 to dicyandiamide of 1:9, 1:4, 3:2, and 4:1, respectively. The mixture obtained before heated to 600 °C in the preparing process of Co/NC-T-1:4 was denoted as Co/NC-T-1:4 precursor. 2.3 Catalyst characterization A Shimadzu XRD 6000 diffractometer from Japan was used to conduct X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis. The light source used was CuKa with a wavelength of 0.154 nm. The tube voltage and current were set at 60 kV and 60 mA, respectively. The scan range was from 10° to 90° with a scan step of 0.02. The surface morphology and microstructure of catalysts were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISSSigma300) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, F200X). A Thermo Scientific K-Alpha energy spectrum analyzer using an AIKa (hv=1486.6 eV) light source was used to perform X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. The experiment was conducted under a vacuum of 5 × 10−7 mbar, with an operating voltage of 12 kV, a filament current of 6 mA, and signal accumulation performed for 5–50 cycles. The full spectrum was examined at a flux energy of 100 eV with increments of 0.1 eV, and the narrow spectrum was examined at a flux energy of 50 eV with increments of 0.1 eV. The C1s binding energy (284.8 eV) peak was utilized for calibrating the XPS peaks of additional elements. A Micromeritics ASAP 2460 device was utilized to conduct N2 adsorption-desorption analysis. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) equation was employed to calculate the specific surface area, while the BJH (Barret-Joyner-Halenda) model was used to obtain the mesopore pore size distribution curves. A Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption apparatus was used to test the H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The moisture was removed in Ar at 200 °C for 1 h, and then Ar was replaced by 10% H2/Ar mixed gasses. Afterwords, the sample was raised to 950 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. A JES-FA200 spectrometer was used to record electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra at 25 °C. The center field was set at 337 mT, with a frequency of 9.5 GHz and a scanning width of 300.0 G. 2.4 Theoretical calculations The Vienna ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) was utilized for all theoretical calculations in this study. The representation of the interaction between electrons and ions utilized the projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotential method. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) method with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) generalized function implantation was adopted to address the exchange-correlation energy. To guarantee the precision of the total energy, a force convergence criterion of 0.05 eV Å −1 and an electron self-consistency convergence criterion of 10−5 eV were utilized. The cutoff energy was 520 eV, and the K point was set as 2 × 2 × 1. Since the cobalt-based catalyst possessed magnetic characteristics, spin polarization was employed in every computation to enhance the precision of forecasting the electronic attributes of the magnetic substance. The Co atoms in the Co (111), and Co (111)-NC structures were corrected using a U correction. The perpendicular direction to the structure plane has a vacuum layer of 20 Å on its surface. The adsorption energy (Eads) was determined using the equation Eads = Etotal- Eslab- EM. Eads represents the energy of adsorption, Etotal denotes the overall energy of a system when it absorbs M atoms or molecules on its surface, Eslab signifies the adsorption energy of the pure surface, and EM refers to the energy of M atoms or molecules. 2.5 Catalytic tests Several as-prepared catalysts were used to perform the HDO reaction of eugenol in a fixed bed reactor. A liquid solution of eugenol/n-heptane (2 wt%) was used as the feed. The reactor was a stainless-steel tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm, a wall thickness of 2 mm, and a length of 500 mm. To ensure gas tightness, N2 was passed through the reactor to displace the air, after which 1 g of catalyst with a mesh size of 40–60 was loaded. Afterwards, a programmed temperature increase was carried out after replacing nitrogen with hydrogen at 3.0 MPa. Eugenol underwent the HDO reaction under specific conditions including a temperature range of 260 °C to 320 °C, a liquid time space velocity (LHSV) between 6 h − 1 and 24 h−1, an H2/oil (H2/liquid feed) volume ratio of 500/1, and a pressure of 3.0 MPa. Liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) reflects the processing capacity of per unit mass catalysts in per unit time. Unless otherwise specified, the LHSV in this paper was calculated based on 1 g catalyst. Following the period of stabilization, the resultant substances underwent condensation, resulting in the collection of liquid products. The liquid product was quantified using n-decane as an internal standard via a gas chromatograph (GC7980, Timex). An FID detector and a DB-5 capillary column, measuring 60 m in length, 0.32 mm in tube diameter, and coated with 0.25 µm thickness, were installed in the chromatograph. The main detection conditions were as follows: the inlet temperature was 270 °C and the splitting ratio was 10:1. The initial temperature of the column chamber was 45 °C, which was held for 7 mins, increased to 80 °C at 10 °C/min, increased to 140 °C at 15 °C/min and held for 5 mins; then, the column chamber was heated to 260 °C at 10 °C/min and held for 5 mins. The internal standard curve method was utilized for quantitative calculations, and the average value was obtained by analyzing each sample three times. The carbon equilibrium consistently fell within the margin of error (less than 5%). The typical carbon balance of eugenol HDO on the Co/NC-T catalyst can be found in Table S2. The calculations of reactant conversion, product selectivity, and carbon balance were performed in the following manners. In summary, PAF-53 was employed as a template agent and was thoroughly combined with a cobalt source and dicyandiamide. Afterwards, the resultant blend was dried and exposed to pyrolysis at a temperature of 900 °C in the presence of a N2 atmosphere. This was then followed by natural cooling, resulting in the formation of Co/NC-T. Furthermore, Co/NC was produced using a comparable synthetic pathway, omitting the presence of PAF-53 and relying exclusively on dicyandiamide as the source of carbon and nitrogen. 3.1 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was performed to reveal the dispersion of Co species (Fig. 1 ). Each of the samples displayed a clear diffraction peak at 44.2°, accompanied by two less prominent reflections at 51.5° and 75.8°, which corresponded to the (111), (200), and (220) reflections of face-centered cubic Co (PDF 15–0806) [41,42], respectively. The presence of the Co characteristic peak indicated that the cobalt ions in the precursor were reduced to Co NPs at high pyrolysis temperatures. In comparison to that of Co/NC without PAF-53, the intensity of the Co diffraction peak in the Co/NC-T catalysts spectrum demonstrated a pattern of initial decrease, subsequent increase, and gradual decrease with the progressive increase in the PAF-53 to dicyandiamide mass ratios. The intensity of Co diffraction peak was correlated with the crystallinity and crystal particle size of Co. The amount of crystallized Co was relevant to the overall Co content. The overall content of Co decreased with the increase in the PAF-53 mass ratio (Table S3). The reduced intensity of Co/NC-T-1:9 compared to Co/NC was primarily ascribed to decrease in Co content and particle size. On the other hand, the enhanced intensity of Co/NC-T-1:4 could probably be attributed to the obvious increase in crystallinity. The Co diffraction peaks of Co/CN2N were observed to be significantly weaker than those of Co/NC-T-3:2, which was probably attributed to decrease in crystallinity and Co content. To investigate the impact of PAF-53 introduction on the specific surface area and porosity of the prepared catalysts, the N2 adsorption-desorption was conducted (Fig. 2 and Fig. S1). All catalysts displayed the isotherms of type IV with H3 hysteresis loops at P/P0 of 0.45–1.0, revealing the presence of mesoporous structures. The hysteresis loop of Co/NC-T-1:4 at P/Po of 0.45–0.80 exhibited significantly greater magnitude compared to the other catalysts, suggesting that Co/NC-T-1:4 possessed the highest proportion of mesopores. Furthermore, the introduction of PAF-53 led to a substantial enhancement of the specific surface area of catalysts, as evidenced by the values presented in Table 1 . Specifically, Co/NC-T-1:4 demonstrated a specific surface area of 153.9 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.42 cm3/g, both of which surpassed the corresponding values for Co/NC (64.8 m2/g and 0.20 cm3/g). Similar trends are observed for Co/NC-T-1:9 and Co/NC-T-3:2. This suggested that the addition of an appropriate amount of PAF-53 during the pyrolysis process served as a pore-expanding agent, thereby facilitating a rise in the specific surface area. However, compared to Co/NC-T-1:4, Co/CN2N derived solely from PAF-53 as a carbon and nitrogen source exhibited a smaller pore volume (0.2 cm3/g) and pore diameter (3.43 nm). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was utilized to examine the electronic chemical states and surface elemental compositions of the catalysts prepared (Fig. 3 ). The XPS full spectra and surface elemental contents confirmed the existence of Co, C, N, and О (Fig. S2 and Table S4). The atomic molar ratio of Co on the surface of catalysts was low compared to overall Co content (Table S3), suggesting that the carbon layers encapsulated the Co particles [42]. This encapsulation may stabilize the Co particles, thereby enhancing the durability of the catalysts. In the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Co2p (Fig. 3), the peak observed at approximately 778.5 eV could be ascribed to the Co 2p3/2 peak (Co0), while the peak observed at around 781.0 eV corresponded to the 2p3/2 peak of the Con+ species (cobalt oxide). However, the characteristic peaks of cobalt oxide were not detected by XRD (Fig. 1), and this may be caused by the excessively small size of the cobalt oxide particles, which could not reflect their distinct diffraction peaks. In Fig. S3a, the XPS spectrum of C1s showed three peaks at 284.8 eV, 286.1 eV, and 286.8 eV. These peaks corresponded to CC/C = C, CN, and CO, respectively. To investigate the N doping, the N1s spectrum was decomposed (Fig. S3b). The peaks observed at 398.8 eV, 399.6 eV, 400.3 eV, and 401.9 eV corresponded to pyridine N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N, and oxidized N, respectively. The presence of pyridine N, graphitic N and oxidized N suggested that N was efficiently doped into the carbon matrix [40,42]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was also conducted to further investigate the impact of the introduction of PAF-53 on the morphology of carbon materials. The results depicted in (a) and (b) of Fig. 4 indicated that a substantial quantity of carbon nanotubes was formed on the surface of Co/NC, which was derived from high-temperature pyrolysis using solely dicyandiamide as the carbon and nitrogen source. However, these carbon nanotubes exhibited a deposited, truncated state, which hindered the mass transfer and diffusion of products during the catalytic reaction. Conversely, when the carbon and nitrogen sources PAF-53 and dicyandiamide (with a mass ratio of 1:4) was employed, a significant quantity of carbon nanotubes exhibiting rough and intertwined walls, as well as loose and porous features, were observed on the Co/NC-T-1:4 surface (Fig. 4c and 5 d). This loose and porous feature of carbon nanotubes was consistent with the large average pore diameter (10.9 nm) of Co/NC-T-1:4. The existence of carbon nanotubes displaying a three-dimensional network structure facilitated the adsorption of reactants, and accelerated the diffusion rate of products while undergoing the catalytic reaction. Nevertheless, the absence of carbon nanotubes was noted on the Co/CN2N catalyst surface when solely employing the triazine polymer PAF-53 as the carbon and nitrogen source. In this case, a partially honeycomb-like rough surface was produced, and columnar shape pores were formed. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed to analyze the effect of adding a suitable amount of PAF-53 on the microstructure and dispersion of catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 5, Co NPs were embedded within nitrogen-doped porous carbon and carbon nanotubes, which were induced during the pyrolysis procedure because of the reducibility of the carbon skeleton. In this context, Co NPs served as “cores” for catalyzing carbon nanotube formation. Compared the TEM image of Co/NC-T-1:4 (Fig. 5c) with that of Co/NC (Fig. 5a), the distribution of Co NPs was somewhat improved for Co/NC-T-1:4. This indicated that the introduction of an appropriate amount of PAF-53 facilitated the distribution of Co NPs. Additionally, a greater dispersion of carbon nanotubes can be observed on the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst, which was consistent with the SEM results. Nevertheless, carbon nanotubes were not observed on the TEM images of Co/NC-T-3:2 and Co/CN2N (Fig. S4). This was probably due to the low contents of Co in Co/NC-T-3:2 and Co/CN2N. Moreover, a decrease in the dispersion of Co NPs was observed in Co/NC-T-3:2 and Co/CN2N (Fig. S4). However, it should be noted that the distribution of Co particle sizes was wide, with some particles seeming to be fully encapsulated within carbon layers. HRTEM analysis was also conducted to offer a thorough understanding of the microstructure and elemental distribution of the Co/NC-T catalysts (Fig. 6 ). The measured lattice distance of 0.205 nm between the metallic particles can be ascribed to the Co(111) lattice plane. The Co/NC-T-1:4 sample primarily consisted of Co, C, N, and O as revealed by elemental mapping images (Fig. 6c and Fig. S5). C and N were distributed within and outside nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes. The presence of a small amount of O can be attributed to the rapid oxidizing of the surface of catalyst in air. However, the peaks of cobalt oxide were not detected by XRD, potentially attributed to the diminutive size of its particles, which rendered them undetectable. Notably, the distribution of N served as evidence for the creation of a nitrogen-doped carbon structure, wherein the nitrogen-doped carbon layer encompassed the Co NPs. The reduction behavior of cobalt species in diverse catalysts was examined via H2-TPR (Fig. 7 ). The reducing behavior of cobalt species in various catalysts was investigated using H2-TPR. The reduction peaks of cobalt species on Co/NC, Co/NC-T-1:4, and Co/CN2N were observed at 535.5 °C, 447.6 °C, and 537.6 °C, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7. It is evident that cobalt species, primarily cobalt oxide, exhibited a higher susceptibility to reduction to Co0 on Co/NC-T-1:4. In comparison, the reduction of Co species to Co0 on Co/NC was more challenging than that on Co/NC-T-1:4, indicating a stronger interaction between Co and the NC support on Co/NC. To better understand the electronic state and interaction between the Co and support, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was utilized to determine the spin state of the unpaired electrons. As shown in Fig. 8 , the characteristic vibration signals of unpaired electrons of nitrogen-doped carbon were observed on both of Co/NC-T-1:4 and Co/NC at approximately 3489 G. The strength of the vibration signals was very weak. This phenomenon can be attributed to the electronic transfer that induced the re-conjugation of individual electrons or the reaction between the support and precursor solution during the deposition of cobalt particles [43]. On the other hand, the g factor of Co/NC-T-1:4 (g = 1.994) was closer to that of free electron (g = 2.0023), comparing with the g factor of Co/NC (g = 1.985). Such result manifested that the electrons on Co/NC-T-1:4 were more mobile than these on Co/NC. The more mobile electrons would obviously promote the surface reaction kinetics [44]. The less electron mobility on Co/NC could be attributed to the greater localization of electrons, hinting the strong interaction between Co and the NC support on Co/NC [43]. Therefore, EPR results confirmed that there was a proper interaction between the Co and nitrogen-doped carbon on Co/NC-T-1:4. Such proper interaction endowed Co/NC-T-1:4 with high mobile electrons. 3.2 DFT calculations The adsorption of reactants on the surface of catalyst is an essential step in catalytic reactions. In this study, the adsorption of eugenol on the surface of a catalyst was investigated through the utilization of density functional theory (DFT). Model structures of Co and Co-N-C were constructed (Fig. S6), which have been previously utilized in the literature [45,46]. Prior studies have shown that metallic Co acts as the active sites in hydrogenation reactions. Therefore, the adsorption energies of eugenol on Co(111) and Co(111)-NC were computed. Typically, eugenol would be involved in two stable adsorbing configurations, namely, parallel adsorption and vertical adsorption. The results presented in Fig. S6 demonstrated that the parallel adsorption energy of eugenol molecules on Co(111)-NC was measured to be −3.08 eV, whereas the vertical adsorption energy was found to be −0.57 eV. These results suggested that the vertical adsorption of eugenol on Co(111)-NC was highly unfavorable. The dominant adsorption configuration was the parallel orientation of the eugenol molecules. On the other hand, the parallel adsorption energy (−3.08 eV) of eugenol molecules on Co(111)-NC was obviously greater than that on Co(111) (−0.76 eV). This indicated that the adsorption of eugenol on Co(111)-NC was much stronger than that on Co(111). The enhanced adsorption of eugenol on Co(111)-NC was reasonably ascribed to the interaction of NC with the surface Co. 3.3 Catalytic performance for eugenol The impact of different pyrolysis temperatures (650 °C, 700 °C, 800 °C, 900 °C, and 1000 °C) on the catalytic performance of the Co/NC catalyst for eugenol HDO to propylcyclohexane was investigated (Fig. S7). Upon increasing the pyrolysis temperature, the Co/NC catalysts achieved complete conversion of eugenol. However, the selectivity of propylcyclohexane exhibited an initial increase followed by a subsequent decrease. When the pyrolysis temperature was increased to 900 °C, the catalyst Co/NC displayed the utmost selectivity of 92.1% towards propylcyclohexane. This may be ascribed to the superior surface cobalt crystallinity on the Co/NC-900 (Fig. S8). The decrease of the selectivity of propylcyclohexane was observed when the pyrolysis temperature raised to 1000 °C, and this may be caused by the aggregation of Co particles at high temperatures. The main product of eugenol HDO was propylcyclohexane, revealing that most of the aromatic rings were saturated by hydrogenation. This could be reasonably explained by the favorable parallel adsorption of eugenol molecules on Co (Fig. S6). However, there was still 6.5% of 4-propylcyclohexanol in the products, suggesting that the capability Co/NC-900 was insufficient for breaking the Caryl-OH bond of eugenol. To enhance the HDO performance of Co/NC, PAF-53 was introduced in different amounts, yielding a series of Co/NC-T catalysts. Fig. 9 displays the HDO performances of Co/NC, Co/NC-T-1:9, Co/NC-T-1:4, Co/NC-T-3:2 and Co/CN2N catalysts for eugenol. It should be noted that the Co mass contents in these catalysts were different (Table S3). The LHSV of 12 h − 1 in Fig. 9 was calculated based on 1 g catalyst (illustrated in “2.5 Catalytic tests”). Here, a specified LHSV of “Co mass in catalyst” (termed LHSVCM), which was calculated based on the Co mass content in catalysts, was used to compare the catalytic performance of different catalysts. The LHSVCM for Co/NC, Co/NC-T-1:9, Co/NC-T-1:4, Co/NC-T-3:2 and Co/CN2N was 19 h−1, 27 h−1, 33 h−1, 53 h−1 and 67 h−1, respectively. All catalysts achieved a 100% conversion of eugenol at 300 °C, indicating their high activity to convert eugenol molecules. However, these catalysts presented disparate selectivity to target product propylcyclohexane. Notably, the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst demonstrated the highest selectivity for propylcyclohexane (98.4%) with negligible selectivity for 4-propylcyclohexanol, manifesting its excellent capability to break Caryl-OH bond. Co/NC and Co/NC-T-1:9 presented worse selectivity for propylcyclohexane than Co/NC-T-1:4, even under lower LHSVCM than Co/NC-T-1:4. Hence, the catalytic performance of Co/NC and Co/NC-T-1:9 was worse than that of Co/NC-T-1:4. At a LHSVCM of 67 h−1, Co/NC-T-1:4 exhibited a propylcyclohexane selectivity of 38.7% (Fig. S9), and this selectivity was far greater than the propylcyclohexane selectivity on Co/CN2N (17.7%) at the LHSVCM of 67 h−1 (Fig. 9). Therefore, the catalytic performance of Co/NC-T-1:4 was obviously superior to Co/CN2N. These results indicated that the incorporation of an optimal amount of PAF-53 could obviously enhance the capability of Co catalysts to cleave the Caryl-OH bonds. The outstanding performance of Co/NC-T-1:4 could be credited to the improvement of its electronic state and spatial structure. The effective interaction between Co and NC-T support (TPR and EPR) favored the distribution of Co NPs on nitrogen-doped carbon (TEM), and improved the proportion of Co and Co0 on the surface (XPS). More importantly, the proper interaction endowed Co/NC-T-1:4 with high mobile electrons (EPR), which was advantageous for the surface reaction kinetics. On the other hand, the introduction of PAF-53 improved the specific surface area (153.9 m2/g), pore volume (0.42 cm3/g), and average pore diameter (10.9 nm) (Table 1) of Co/NC-T-1:4. Especially, the existence of loose and porous carbon nanotubes in Co/NC-T-1:4 (SEM and TEM) facilitated the adsorption of eugenol, and accelerated the diffusion rate of products. The impacts of different reaction temperatures on the catalytic performance of Co/NC-T-1:4 was shown in Fig. 10 . Notably, the eugenol transformation rate remained unwaveringly at 100% while the reaction temperature escalated from 260 °C to 320 °C. Nevertheless, the selectivity of propylcyclohexane was strongly affected by the temperature of the reaction. At 260 °C, the predominant product was 4-propyl cyclohexol, which accounted for 82.7% of the total product, while the selectivity of propylcyclohexane was only 14.7%. As the reaction temperature rose, the selectivity of 4-propylcyclohexanol gradually decreased, while the selectivity of propylcyclohexane exhibited a significant increase. At a reaction temperature of 300 °C, the selectivity of propylcyclohexane reached its highest 98.4%. At a reaction temperature of 320 °C, the presence of partial propylbenzene and 4-propylcyclohexanol was observed, while propylcyclohexane exhibited an obvious decrease. This was caused by the generation of propylbenzene, which was probably favored by high reaction temperature. The catalysts Co/NC and Co/CN2N also followed similar hydrodeoxygenation pathways (Fig. S10) at varying reaction temperatures. Additionally, the selectivity of Co/NC-T-1:4 was influenced by the liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV). According to Fig. S9, the selectivity of propylcyclohexane exhibited a gradual increase with increasing LHSV, followed by a subsequent decrease. This observation suggested that at lower values of LHSV, the prolonged contact time between the reactants and the catalyst promoted further degradation of the formed propylcyclohexane, resulting in the formation of n-hexane [14]. Conversely, at higher values of LHSV, the contact time was too short for the transformation of the intermediate 4-propylcyclohexanol to the target propylcyclohexane, leading to an excessive accumulation of 4-propylcyclohexanol and a decrease in the selectivity of propylcyclohexane. The reaction process was analyzed based on the reactive behavior of eugenol over the as-prepared Co catalysts (Fig. 10, Fig. S9 and Fig. S10). Under certain circumstances, the existence of 2‑methoxy-4-propylphenol, 4-propylphenol, 4-propylcyclohexanol and propylbenzene was observed. However, the absence of the 3-propylanisole indicated that Caryl–OCH3 was broken before the Caryl-OH bond. 2‑methoxy-4-propylphenol and 4-propylphenol appeared under high LHSV of 24 h−1 (Fig. S9), but neither were detected at a low LHSV. These results indicated that the transformation of 2‑methoxy-4-propylphenol and 4-propylphenol was swift. When the reaction temperature was below 290 °C (Fig. 10), 4-propylcyclohexanol emerged as the primary secondary product. Furthermore, it was consistently noted that the decline in the selectivity of 4-propylcyclohexanol coincided with the rise in the selectivity of the desired product propylcyclohexane. Hence, it can be deduced that the conversion of 4-propylcyclohexanol to propylcyclohexane was the key step in the HDO of eugenol to propylcyclohexane. Based on above findings, we proposed a potential reaction pathway (Scheme 3 ). Eugenol rapidly underwent hydrogenation on the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst, resulting in the production of mainly 2‑methoxy-4-propylphenol. This transformation primarily occurred through the parallel adsorption configuration of eugenol on the Co sites of the catalyst. Afterwards, the Caryl–OCH3 bond of 2‑methoxy-4-propylphenol was swiftly cleaved, leading to the formation of 4-propylphenol. Following this, the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst facilitated the hydrogenation saturation of 4-propylphenol to 4-propylcyclohexol. Finally, the Caryl-OH bonds of 4-propylcyclohexol were broken to yield desired product propylcyclohexane, and this was the rate-determining step during the HDO process of eugenol. The improved dispersion and electronic properties of the Co NPs by the introduction of PAF-53 played a significant role in efficiently breaking Caryl-OH bonds in this step. On the other hand, another less important generating path of propylcyclohexane via 4-propylphenol to propylbenzene also existed. However, this insignificant path was at a noteworthy disadvantageous position compared to the primary pathway involving 4-propylcyclohexol. In other words, the saturation of the benzene ring of 4-propylphenol through hydrogenation was prioritized instead of breaking the Caryl-OH bonds of 4-propylphenol. Clearly, the hydrogenation saturation of benzene rings was preferred due to the parallel adsorption configuration. The stability of the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst was investigated by conducting eugenol HDO to generate propylcyclohexane. The catalyst lifespan experiments, as depicted in Fig. 11 , revealed that even after 108 h of continuous reactions, the conversion of eugenol consistently remained at 100%, albeit with a slight decrease in the selectivity of propylcyclohexane by approximately 11.9%. This observation suggested that the catalyst exhibited favorable overall stability. The scalability of the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst was assessed using various phenolic derivatives (Table S5). All these phenolic derivatives can be highly efficiently converted into their corresponding products. For example, the conversion of isoeugenol was 100% and the selectivity of propylcyclohexane was 94.4% for the HDO of isoeugenol. Generally, Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst gave high selectivity to the breaking of Caryl–OCH3 bonds. However, the influence of substituent groups on the breaking of Caryl-OH bonds was evident, emphasizing the distinctive HDO capability of the Co/NC-T-1 4 catalyst. 4 Conclusions The incorporation of PAF-53 resulted in enhancements in the textural, chemical, and electronic characteristics of Co/NC-T. Specifically, the integration of PAF-53 led to an increase in both the pore volume and pore diameter of the catalyst, and facilitated the formation of nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes. Furthermore, the introduction of an appropriate proportion of PAF-53 was favorable to the dispersion of Co particles. Additionally, the reduction behavior of cobalt species was improved. Notably, the incorporation of PAF-53 endowed Co/NC-T-1:4 with high mobile electrons, which was advantageous for the surface reaction kinetics. The capability of Co/NC-T-1:4 to cleave the Caryl-OH bond was enhanced, and the adsorption of eugenol molecules was strengthened. Thereby, the selectivity of propylcyclohexane in the hydrogenation of eugenol was noticeably improved. coredata.dc:description: It is highly significant to develop effective catalysts made from non-precious metals for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) process of eugenol to propylcyclohexane. A triazine polymer (PAF-53) was employed as a template to synthesize a highly potential Co/NC-T (nitrogen-doped carbon modified by template) catalyst through one-pot pyrolysis method, aiming to facilitate the HDO reaction of eugenol. The results of the characterization indicated that Co nanoparticles (NPs) were incorporated within the structure of nitrogen-doped carbon. Adding the suitable quantity of PAF-53 could improve the distribution of Co NPs, increase the specific area and average pore diameter, and facilitate the generation of numerous carbon nanotubes that are sparse and porous. Furthermore, the incorporation of PAF-53 improved the interaction between Co and nitrogen-doped carbon, and endowed Co/NC-T with high mobile electrons. As revealed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, the adsorption of eugenol molecules was obviously enhanced, and the parallel adsorption configuration was remarkably favorable. The conversion of eugenol over Co/NC-T-1:4 reached 100% and the selectivity of propylcyclohexane reached 98.4%, at 300 °C, 3 MPa H2 and a liquid hourly space velocity of 12 h−1. Moreover, the Co/NC-T-1:4 catalyst exhibited remarkable durability and scalability during the HDO process of eugenol.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrodeoxygenation of lignin-derived eugenol to propylcyclohexane over triazine polymer derived Co/NC-T catalyst
